text: thinking about it - i would suggest doing a *git fetch* rather than git pull … then in case you save your own work in that repo folder it wont be overwritten - a bit safer

git fetch
rather than git pull … then in case you save your own work in that repo folder it wont be overwritten - a bit safer

text:
<!channel>,
if you finish the `Lab | Customer Analysis Round 2` you will realize that the date column contains only entries for January and February. So obviously the exercise to filter for Jan/Feb/Mar is a bit dull.

So I overwrote the month number in the csv with random integers. You can give that csv a try, if you want to have it a bit more spiced up :grin:

elements.text:
,

Lab | Customer Analysis Round 2

So I overwrote the month number in the csv with random integers. You can give that csv a try, if you want to have it a bit more spiced up

text: Ok, the dataset will give you an error if you solved the lab properly. Here's why: I subsituted the month part of the values in that `effective_to_date` column randomly with values between 1 and 12. So far so logical. But then also date values with for example "7/31/11" got the 7 subsituted for a 2, which would make it February the 31st, which doesn't exist and since pandas datetime is smart, it will throw you an error like this (screenshot). So, better not use my data :grin:, or: *Bonus quest*: Fix my data so that for all Februaries the days are valid :nerd_face:

elements.text: Ok, the dataset will give you an error if you solved the lab properly. Here's why: I subsituted the month part of the values in that
effective_to_date

column randomly with values between 1 and 12. So far so logical. But then also date values with for example "7/31/11" got the 7 subsituted for a 2, which would make it February the 31st, which doesn't exist and since pandas datetime is smart, it will throw you an error like this (screenshot). So, better not use my data
, or:
Bonus quest
: Fix my data so that for all Februaries the days are valid

Thank you!
